title: Head-to-Head Battle of Coin Flip Strategies
assignment: Consider a fair coin and two players Alice and Bob. They flip a coin \(N\)-times. Alice gets a point for each pair of two consecutive heads \(\mathsf{HH}\), including cases where heads overlap (i.e., \(\mathsf{HHH}\) yields two points). Bob gets a point for each pair of heads followed by tails \(\mathsf{HT}\). The winner is a player who scored more points. On average, who wins more games? What are the respective win rates and how much percent of games ends in a draw?

title: Random Walk on a Bridge
assignment: A (one-dimensional) bridge is \(30\) meters wide. A "random walker" starts \(10\) meters from the right end of the bridge. Each second, the walker takes a \(1\,\text{m}\) step with equal probability to the left or to the right. If the walker reaches the left end of the bridge, he falls off. What is the probability that the walker falls off the bridge on the left side (in the limit of infinite time)?

title: Just a Simple Limit
hints: Notice, that we are summing over Poisson distribution.
For given \(n\), we have Poisson distribution with a mean \(n\).
Poisson for big \(n\) looks like _______ distribution (possible to derive using Central Limit Theorem).

title: Asymptotic behaviour of the number of directory tree structures
assignment: Let us imagine a system of folders, where every folder can have up to \(d\) files (another folders) in it -we get an example of tree structure. What is the asymptotic behaviour (as number of folders \(N\) goes to infinity) of possible structures of this type ? Note that the graph tree is labeled(different folders) -this gets us more combinatorical additions.
hints: Try to rephrase the problem using power series -in particular construct the generating function for the numbers of possible structures.
Find recursive relation for the sum of this power series.
Utilizing the recursive relation can we find the radius of convergence of this series? Can it tell us something about the sought for number of structures?
Use the ratio test for convergence of the series.

title: Generating function for partitions (partition function)
assignment:
Partition function \(p(n)\) represents number of possible partitions of a non-negative integer \(n\) into a sum of non-negative integers. For example, \(p(4)=5\) since \(4\) has \(5\) partitions, namely \(1+1+1+1\), \(1+1+2\), \(2+2\), \(1+3\), and finally \(4\). Find the generating function for the partition function.

What about generating function for strict partitions (no part occurs more than once), or generating function for partitions with only odd parts? Is there some relation between them?
hints: Come up with a scheme of encoding any partition of an arbitrary number.
Form a sum through all possible partitions with a proper weight.
Use the geometric series formula to simplify the sum.
